dialogues.speaker: EXT. BOARDWALK AMUSEMENT PARK. BOTTLE TOSS BOOTH. NIGHT
dialogues.text: It’s 1986. A colorful vibrant energy. Pedestrians walk along the boardwalk past game booths and souvenir stands as a ROLLE COASTER SCREAMS by overhead. ADELAIDE (9, African American) wears a “Hands Across Amer T-shirt, and her hair up in pigtails. She holds a candied apple, and watches, her father, RUSSELL (33, African American) hurl a baseball and TOPPLES a pyramid of bottle a “Bottle-Pyramid” booth. He’s clearly in a bad mood and takes it out on the bottles. RAYNE, Adelaide’s mother, (30, African American) CLAPS obligatorily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The booth attendant, DANNY, a stoner, feigns excitement. Judging by their physical energies, Rayne and Russell had huge fight earlier. Russell picks up a beer.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Great shot. You put some heat on that.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Thanks. I guess I missed my chance to go pro.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You can get a prize from the second level or keep goin’ for a prize from the third level.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: What you think, Addy? Should we stop or keep goin’? Adelaide looks at Rayne.

dialogues.speaker: RAYNE
dialogues.text: Don’t look at me; it’s your birthday. Adelaide points to a T-shirt.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: I want that one.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Yeah alright. That one. Russell takes the shirt, then takes Adelaide’s candied ap and hands it to Rayne. RUSSELL (CONT’D) Here... Moments later...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BOARDWALK AMUSEMENT PARK. MAIN STRIP. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Adelaide lags behind Rayne and Russell as they stroll dow the strip. She wears a new oversized “Michael Jackson's Thriller” t-shirt.

dialogues.speaker: RAYNE
dialogues.text: (To Russell) That shirt better not give her nightmares.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: In trouble for buyin’ my daughter a shirt. That’s a new one.

dialogues.speaker: RAYNE
dialogues.text: She got scared when it was on TV. You'd know that if you were around.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Who let her watch it?

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: I wasn’t scared.

dialogues.speaker: RAYNE
dialogues.text: You hid your eyes when the people came out the ground.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: (To Rayne) I need another beer. Adelaide turns her head and sees a drunk sailor, TED spil his drink on his white uniform.

dialogues.speaker: RAYNE
dialogues.text: Mmmm Hmmm.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: I can’t have a beer now?

dialogues.speaker: RAYNE
dialogues.text: You can do whatever you want.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Okay then. The ROLLERCOASTER RUMBLES BY again; Adelaide watches it. screams startle her a little. They pass fast food RUSSELL (CONT’D) What about The Dipper? Hey Addy, you wanna try it?

dialogues.speaker: RAYNE
dialogues.text: You know she’s not big enough, and I sure as Hell am not going on that thing. a table where two teenagers, MANDY and DOWNEY, eat like pigs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moments later, Adelaide, Rayne, and Russell arrive at the Whac-A-Mole booth.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: ‘Whac-A-Mole’! This is my game. (To the booth attendant, TROY) How many tickets, four?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Russell slams four tickets down, grabs the tethered malle and starts playing.

dialogues.speaker: RAYNE
dialogues.text: Addy, come to the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: I don’t have to go.

dialogues.speaker: RAYNE
dialogues.text: Russ, will you watch your daughter, please?

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: I'm watching... He’s not. He’s playing Whac-A-Mole. Rayne heads off. Adel watches Russell for a moment before her attention turns t the ocean. She walks towards the edge of the boardwalk. A young homeless man, YOUNG FERDIE, lurks by the wooden staircase leading to the beach. He’s clutching a cardboar sign with a bible verse scrawled across it. “Jeremiah 11: is written boldly and Young Adelaide stares at the number as she passes him. He looks right at her. Two teens, GLEN and NANCY, flirtatiously play “Rock Paper Scissors.” They keep landing on the same combination over over.

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: Oh my god

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: That's impossible. They do it again. They land on scissors.

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: What the hell?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: How are you doing that?

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: I’m not doing anything. You are.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BEACH NEAR THE BOARDWALK. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Adelaide walks down the stairs, and onto the beach where few teenagers act wild by a small campfire. Adelaide passes by the teenagers as she walks towards the water’s edge.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BEACH NEAR THE WATER. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Moments later... She approaches the shoreline and scans the dark horizon. the distance, a large cloud erupts in silent lightning. A a breath, she turns back towards the boardwalk. One attraction faces her on the beach level underneath th boardwalk. It’s called “SHAMAN’S VISION QUEST”, a Native American mystical themed funhouse with an entrance that f the water. The facade is painted to resemble a forest wit colorful images of spirit-animals and a large Shaman who glares, pointing his finger directly at Adelaide. Signs n the arched doorway read “GET LOST” and “FIND YOURSELF.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adelaide walks toward the Vision Quest portal.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BEACH NEAR THE BOARDWALK. NIGHT
dialogues.text: She drops the candied apple which falls onto the sand. As Adelaide gets near the entrance, a THUP or two of thick r drops hit the sand. The crowd over at the boardwalk MURMU

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adelaide enters just as the rain hits full on.

dialogues.speaker: INT. VISION QUEST. FOREST ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Adelaide enters The Vision Quest, and goes down a hallway made to feel like a magical walk through a dark forest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The walls are dressed and painted like woods, with the occasional eerily pleasant deer, rabbits and eagles. A CACOPHONOUS RECORDING OF NATURE SOUNDS plays over hidden speakers. A cast-plastic owl on a branch pounces out from a dark crevice startling Adelaide with a “HOO HOO”. The owl emit HISS OF PRESSURIZED AIR and returns to its starting point Adelaide calms herself, and continues into the maze.

dialogues.speaker: INT. VISION QUEST. HALL OF MIRRORS. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Adelaide enters a room that’s still forest themed but als covered in mirrors. She walks past several distorted reflections. A short one, a weird one, and a weirder one. With a RUMBLE OF LIGHTNING the lights go out, and the FOR NOISE STOPS. What was kinda eerie when lit becomes downri terrifying when dark. The only light comes from the glowing red exit sign. She walks towards it but hits a mirror. She looks up. The “EX sign appears forwards and backwards, over and over again infinite reflections. Adelaide reaches her hands out and tries to make her way down the mirrored wall. She begins whistling “ITSY BITSY SPIDER” again to make he feel at ease, but she stops in near panic when a WHISTLE the halls overtakes hers. Somebody, somewhere in the mirr labyrinth is whistling in an attempt to emulate her tune. Something her size SCURRIES QUICKLY across the hallway. Adelaide backs up almost against a mirror. She slowly beg to turn 180 degrees to face the mirror behind her, but HE REFLECTION DOESN'T TURN!!! This isn’t a mirror, its the b of another identical girl's head. Black.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CLASSROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Closeup on a red wet rabbit’s eye. “ug” MUSIC: A CHILDREN’S CHOIR HUMS A DARK ANTHEM IN A STRANGE

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: We slowly pull away. The rabbit sits in a brass cage agai a tiled wall. We pull out to reveal more and more rabbits cages stacked one on top of the other.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAR. RURAL ROAD. DAY
dialogues.text: We look out the rear window past stick figure stickers depicting father, mother, daughter and son. The Wilson's travels through a rural road where woods and beach meet. EXT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. DAY The Wilson's car arrives. INT. THE WILSON’S CAR. DAY ADELAIDE WILSON (African American, now 34) wakes up in th passenger seat she looks over at GABE WILSON (African American, 34), a large man with glasses who thinks he’s a cooler than he is, in the driver’s seat. Gabe holds his finger in front of his mouth like “Shhhhh”. Adelaide know where this is going. They look at the kids asleep in the back, ZORA WILSON, (African American, 13) and JASON WILSO (African American, 11).

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: (yelling) We made it!!!! The kids wake up in panic. Gabe LAUGHS.

dialogues.speaker: ZORA JASON
dialogues.text: Why???? Noooo.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: ‘Cause y’all sleep too much. EXT. WILSON'S BAYSIDE HOUSE. DRIVEWAY. DAY. The Wilsons emerge. Adelaide looks down the road ponderou Jason starts wandering off. Jason goes to the back of the car to get his bag. Zora ch her phone.

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: Wifi isn’t working.  10.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: You don’t need the internet. Out here you’ve got... the “Outernet.”

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: Good one.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Hey, little man! Bags inside first. Jason runs back and Gabe hands him his bag.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can we rewind her?

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: I don’t think they work like that.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Just one year. She laughs. Gabe kisses her neck real quick and goes insi INT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. KITCHEN BREAKFAST TABLE. DAY We pass through the Wilson’s foyer. Hanging on the wall a pictures of Adelaide at different stages of life with Rus and Rayne. There’s one of her at fourteen in ballet class There are also pictures of Zora and Jason with their grandmother.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: What do you call a cow with no legs... Ground beef.

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: (dryly) Ha ha.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Get it? ‘Cause he’s on the ground?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: We get it.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You should practice while you're here. ZORA (0.S. Uch, okay.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What..?

dialogues.speaker: ZORA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Why you got attitude?

dialogues.speaker: ZORA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) I’m sorry. Yay, track and field. We find the Wilsons eating fast food in the breakfast noo Zora and Gabe power through their food. Jason sits quietl occasionally snapping his right hand. He wears a plastic werewolf mask on his head. Adelaide eats strawberries out a tupperware container. She plays with her food a little. No.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Whoa. Really..? You’re over running now?

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: You love track and field.

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: What’s the point?

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: The Olympics.

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: I’m not gonna make it into the Olympics.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: You can do anything you set your mind to.

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: Can I drive while we’re up here?

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE GABE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: That's what I set my mind to. I set my mind to driving.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Change your mind.  12.

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: Why not? Jason runs off to his room.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Because we said so. (To Jason) Jason! Finish your food, please!

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: Cara and Haley drove with parent supervision.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: You don’t need to drive when you are an Olympic caliber athlete... You run.

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: My God.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: You should run on the sand.

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: ‘Cause it’s harder; no traction. You practice on the beach, when you get on solid ground, you’ll take off. Adelaide is caught off guard by the mention of the beach.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: We're going to the beach?

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Yeah... later... I thought we’d go when we’re settled...

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Cool.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: What beach?

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Santa Cruz. The boardwalk. I told you about this.  13.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: No. You didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Josh and Kitty and the girls’1l be there. Adelaide and Zora share an eye roll.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Do we have to sell grandma's house? Gabe looks to Adelaide before he answers.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Well... It’s not that "we have to”--

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: --We have to because school is too expensive, and coming here once a year doesn’t make it worth it. Another awkward silence. Jason's constant snapping linger

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: It’s a magic trick. I left it here last year.

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: Okay... Let’s see it. Everyone looks expectantly. Jason snaps again; nothing happens. They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: This thing is bullshit..

dialogues.speaker: GABE ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Whoa! Excuse me. Gabe points at Jason.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: You cursing at the table now?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: (mumbling to Gabe) When you point a finger at someone else, you have three pointing back at you.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: What the hell is that supposed to mean?

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: I think it means you curse at the table too. Gabe grumbles and goes back to eating. Gabe looks

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Well it’s four fingers, anyway... Four fingers pointing back at you.

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: One’s a thumb... and it’s not pointing at you.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Go to your room. at his hand for a second then brushes it off. INT. PSYCHIATRIST’S OFFICE. DAY Young Adelaide sits intense and still on a sofa. Though t sliver of open door, she can see Russell and Rayne speaki with DR. FOSTER.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOSTER
dialogues.text: I think she has Post Traumatic Stress Disorder.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: What...? She wasn’t in Nam’; she got lost for fifteen minutes.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOSTER
dialogues.text: That can be very scary.

dialogues.speaker: RAYNE
dialogues.text: We don’t know what happened to her.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: So, how do we get her to talk?

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOSTER
dialogues.text: I could meet with her once a week.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Mmm hmm. For how long?

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOSTER
dialogues.text: I think we need to encourage her to draw, write... dance... anything to help her tell us her story... but we have to be patient. Rayne quietly weeps. Dr. Foster passes her a tissue. Russ goes to touch Rayne but she pulls away. Russell le

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: I’m gonna have a smoke. aves. PRESENT DAY...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adelaide lays on the couch looking at one of Jason’s rubb spider toys. A real spider climbs across it. Gabe unpacks with a pep in his step in a nearby room.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (On the phone) Yeah, we'll see... Well, that’s a coincidence... Listen... listen... I’m not gonna say anything but “wait for it.” You’ll see.. You’1ll see... INT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. FOYER/LIVING ROOM. DAY Gabe finishes his call as Adelaide looks at the spider.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: (On the phone) Why would I lie? Alright..? See you soon. He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That was Josh. We’1ll leave in an hour.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: We just got here.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: They stayed an extra day so we could meet up...  16.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Off her reaction.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What? You don’t like Josh and Kitty now?

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Eh...

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Damn... It’s like that? Okay. Name one thing wrong with Josh and Kit--

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: --They drink too much.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Okay... Two things.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Gabe...

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Zora and the girls get along.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: What’s the point of a summer home by the beach if you never go to the beach.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: There’s a beach just down that hill.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: That’s not a beach. It’s a shore. That's a bay. I’m talking about a real beach. Sand; an amusement park; people...

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: There are weirdos at that beach. Gabe realizes there’s something deeper going on.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Okay... okay. I’1ll cancel... Just sucks... I know Jason was looking forward to it... First time back after grandma died... I think being here is hitting him hard.  17.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: (begrudgingly) We leave there before it gets dark.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Hell yeah; it’s gonna be fun. He goes for a kiss. She laughs and playfully pushes him a

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don’t have to kiss me. You’re in trouble for later, tho. He heads to the door. She can tell he’s up to something.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Oh you think so?

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Oh yes.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Taking out the trash. I’1l be right back. Gabe hustles out with a mischievous smirk. INT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. HALLWAY. DAY Adelaide passes Zora’s room.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Where’s your brother? Zora shrugs. Adelaide opens the basement door. INT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. BASEMENT. DAY Adelaide walks down to the basement. There is a washer, a dryer, and a table for folding laund in front of a mirrored wall. She finds a box and opens it. They are pictures of her as child in a ballerina tutu. There’s also an old stuffed bu  18.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She smiles with melancholic nostalgia. Out of nowhere, “Y Adelaide” spins through the space. This was a mini ballet practice studio. INT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. BATHROOM. DAY Zora enters and shuts the door. She looks in the mirror. leans in examining a blemish when... Jason bursts out of cabinet and scampers out the door. INT. THE WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. BASEMENT. DAY Adelaide watches her fourteen-year-old self, “Teen Adelai dance, now with perfect pirouettes. Footsteps thump above INT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. HALLWAY. DAY Jason enters the closet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door begins to creak shut, but he puts a toy ambulanc the crack, propping the door open for a sliver of light. Jason pulls his mask down and resumes snapping. After a f unsuccessful snaps, he pauses. INT. THE WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. HALLWAY. DAY Zora walks down the hallway and nonchalantly bumps the to ambulance into the closet with her heel. The closet door shuts. INT. THE WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. HALLWAY. DAY Jason grabs the doorknob from inside, jiggling it. It’s locked. INT. THE WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. BASEMENT. DAY Adelaide watches Teen Adelaide dance when Jason SCREAMS upstairs. Adelaide is startled. INT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. ZORA'S ROOM. DAY Adelaide passes the open doorway to Zora’s room. She’s pissed.  19.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: You can’t help him? Zora is laying on the bed with headphones on. She turns a her mom passes by.

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: What happened? INT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. HALLWAY. DAY Adelaide opens the closet door. Jason sits there.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Oh baby. That’s why you can’t play in there. Jason’s tears turn to rage.

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: Didn't this happen last year?

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Zora, please... The moment is broken by a DISTANT BUZZ that starts small gets closer.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey! The three of them look at each other..

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BAYSIDE. DAY
dialogues.text: Adelaide, Zora and Jason stand on the dock by their house Gabe, a pillar of pride, stands triumphantly at the steer wheel of a small motor boat that buzzes around in circles beams while Adelaide, Zora and Jason remain thoroughly unimpressed.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Well... What’dya think?! “Craw- Daddy”!

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: (unimpressed) Wow.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: It’s got a cassette player and everything... All it needs is a new coat of paint! They just watch him. He holds up a life preserver.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, “J”, look!. It even came with one of these! The boat engine SPUTTERS TO A HALT. Smoke bellows from it Gabe goes

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: (to Adelaide) He’s kidding right?

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: (under her breath) He’s not kidding.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Hold up. He told me how to fix this. to the back of the boat and pounds it with his fist a couple times.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t worry. I got it real cheap!

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: I would hope so.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: She veers a little to the left, so you have to stay on it, but other than that it’s perfect!

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: You think?

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Also, Josh got a boat, so we can do a dual-family voyage.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Ah. I see.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Josh's boat is probably way better.  21.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: He said Josh’s boat is probably better.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: It’s not a contest. It’s something I thought would be nice for the family.

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: But will we all fit tho?

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Okay, you know what? Y’all are spoiled. The engine starts up again. Gabe almost falls. Adelaide a Zora are amused. INT. WILSON’S CAR. DAY Gabe pouts as he drives through a road lined with redwood trees. The rest of the family chills in their seats. Jaso snaps in the back. Zora reads. Adelaide checks in on Gabe mood.

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: Did you know this country produces, like twice as much waste per capita as any other country in the developed world? No one responds. Jason looks at her dryly.

dialogues.speaker: ZORA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I forgot. No one cares about the environment.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Since when did you become such a tree hugger?

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: I’m not a tree hugger.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: I like it. I’m just saying. Zora watches Jason continue to snap.  22.

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: ..-Maybe you could just tell us what’s supposed to happen and we can picture it. He keeps snapping.

dialogues.speaker: ZORA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mean, at a certain point--

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: --Kiss my anus, Zora.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Oh!

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: What?!? Zora is shocked, and Adelaide tries to hide her smile.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Why are we even talkin’ bout “anuses?”

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: “Anus” isn’t a curse word.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: That doesn’t matter.

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: Disgusting.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: See I would’ve preferred a curse word in this case.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: (To Adelaide) I can see you laughing in the mirror. Gabe leans on the horn.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: OK, you know what? We don’t always need to be talking. There are families that enjoy silence. The rest of them look around “yeesh”. Adelaide knows her family. She turns on the radio. “I Got Five On It” by Lun is on. Gabe’s mood immediately lifts.  23.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “I got Five on it...” He grooves in his seat. Zora and Jason share a look.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: What does “I got five on it” mean?

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: It’s about drugs.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: It’s a dope song; don’t do drugs.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Jason. Get it in rhythm. She starts snapping to the rhythm. Jason follows along. Gabe loosens up and sit dances singing along.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: “I got five on it...” Zora and Adelaide share a look through the rearview mirro Adelaide shrugs. Zora rolls her eyes in pleasant conceit.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. REDWOOD ROAD. DAY
dialogues.text: The car drives past more redwood trees. INT. WILSON’S CAR. TRANSITIONAL ROAD. DAY They emerge from the wood-lined road and overlook downtow Santa Cruz’s amusement park, boardwalk and beach. The rollercoaster looms menacingly in the distance. Adelaide hides her apprehension as they head towards the scene of her past horror.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAR. CROSSWALK. DAY
dialogues.text: The car arrives at a crosswalk. A CROSSING GUARD steps ou front of the car and stops them. They wait while a line o leave sailors crosses the street in front of the Wilson’s car.

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: Why can’t I drive in the parking lot?  24.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: You’re not old enough.

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: I’m not talking to you.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Hmm, let me think about that for a second... no.

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Because I cherish my life. As the sailors pass, Adelaide watches the town go by and remains preoccupied with thought. FLASHBACK... INT. RAYNE’S CAR. NIGHT Rayne drives away from the rainy beach. We can’t quite he words but can tell that Russell is drunk. He and Rayne ar Young Adelaide sits in the backseat in total shock. PRESENT DAY... INT. WILSON’S CAR. ROAD TO AMUSEMENT PARK. DAY

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Ahhh. Damn it. Adelaide snaps out of her daydream. They’ve just turned a corner and ended up stuck behind an ambulance and cop car that block the street.

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: Oh my God. A couple of COPS are taking statements from locals on the sidewalk who witnessed the incident at hand. Two EMTs loa unconscious bleeding homeless man into the ambulance.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Don’t look. Don’t look.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: You gotta be kidding me. A cop waves the car past. Jason watches the man.  25.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BEACH. BY THE BOARDWALK. DAY
dialogues.text: The Wilsons, having parked, step onto the sand carrying folding chairs and other beach gear. As they walk, Adelai fights the urge to look behind her. Eventually she steals nonchalant glance back in the direction of where the ‘Vis Quest’ was when she was a child. The attraction is still there, but it’s name has been changed to ‘Merlin’s Forest It still has the same “FIND YOURSELF” sign, but the Shama has been replaced with an old white wizard who still poin his finger outwards like a bizarro Uncle Sam.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Was that guy dead?

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: The guy in the ambulance?

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Ambulance means he’s alive, right? Jason, unsure, nods and starts snapping again.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BEACH. PICNIC. DAY
dialogues.text: They arrive at the Tyler family’s beach set-up: umbrella, chairs, and a stocked cooler already set up in tidy order JOSH TYLER (Caucasian 40) KITTY TYLER (Caucasian 40) sit. Josh and Kitty are both a couple drinks in. The Tyler twins LINDSEY and BECCA (Caucasian 14) play by water.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Ay!

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: Yay!

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: You said 2:30! Where’s your efficiency, man? Efficiency!

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: We got held up.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH KITTY
dialogues.text: I'm kidding, don’t worry Hey girl. about it.  26.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: We made it.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: Oh my God. Zora, you’ve gotten so big! You look so pretty?

dialogues.speaker: ZORA JOSH
dialogues.text: (Hates the compliment) Hey, Jason. You want a beer? Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Um...

dialogues.speaker: KITTY ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: (To Zora) (To Jason) Lindsey and Becca will be No. The answer is “no.” happy to see you. (To Josh) Please give me a couple more years.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY JOSH
dialogues.text: (to Becca and Lindsey) (To Jason) Guys, look who’s here! I kid. Here’s a soda. Becca flies a kite, Lindsey does cartwheels. They wave. Z gives her mom an “I hate these bitches” look before walki over to them. (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: Hi, Jason! Jason waves shyly as he walks off. LATER... The two families chill on the beach. Zora sits near the t who practice gymnastics. Jason plays nearby in the sand. Gabe and Josh pal around, pouring beers into plastic cups cracking each other up.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Have you taken her on her maiden voyage yet?

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Just rode her home. But we’re gonna do the family thing soon.  27.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Cool. We could do a double excursion.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I mean, it’s small, but it’s a real classic design.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Hey, it’s not about the size of the boat...

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: ..-The fuck outta here. Josh laughs.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Kitty! Kitty who is talking to Adelaide looks over.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You hear Gabe got a boat?

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: Oh? Cool.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: He says “it’s small.” I said, “It’s not the size of the boat...”

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: (to Josh) Wow. You thought that bared repeating. .?

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: He did though. He really did.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Screw all of you. Adelaide glances back again still distracted by the ‘Merl Forest’. Kitty clocks it.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: ‘Merlin’s Forest’...?

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: I think that changed. It used to be called ‘Vision Quest.’

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: Oh, how culturally insensitive of them...

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Totally.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Addy, beer, wine, vodka cran? Mimosa? I got everything.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Do you have water?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Um... I’ve got ice. 28. He hands her a cup of ice. Then passes kitty a drink. He pulls her drink away before giving it to her. practical joke.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: I hate you. (to Adelaide) It never stops. I honestly think about murdering him sometimes. Adelaide laughs.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: So nothing’s new.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: Actually. Since you asked... The old lame Kitty smiles. She turns her head showcasing her face from different angles.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: What..? What...? Oh my God. Did you have something “done?";

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: Just an itsy-bitsy thing..

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Fuck off. You look exactly the same as you did last year.  29.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: That’s the idea. A little bit goes a long way. Not that you need it you beautiful motherfucker. Adelaide quietly doesn’t accept the compliment. She looks around the beach.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Stop. I can already tell the things you think are flaws are so annoying. Adelaide almost says something, but doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: I'm kidding. Tell me...

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Sometimes I have a hard time... talking.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: You ever wonder “what if... What if things had happened differently?”

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: I don’t know what you mean?

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: You mean the What-if-I-never-got- married-and-had-kids question? Um, yeah. I’m having it literally right now. Trust me. The girls have just gotten to the age where I feel like I can finally go to the spa once a week for ‘me time.’

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: “Me time?” What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: It’s mandatory.  30. DOWN BY THE WATER... Becca approaches Jason. Lindsey does cartwheels. She land the sand structure he’s making.

dialogues.speaker: LINDSEY
dialogues.text: (to Jason) Oops. Oh shit! My bad. Lindsey continues cartwheeling back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: It doesn’t matter. Becca offers Jason the kite reel.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Wanna try? It’s pretty dumb, but you might like it.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Um. Okay.

dialogues.speaker: LINDSEY
dialogues.text: The wind’s good. Jason tries to fly the kite. Lyndsey cartwheels over to Z who reads on the beach.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Your brother's so weird.

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: He just has a problem focusing. They look over at Jason who tries to fly the kite while watching his own hand snap.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Are you going in the water..?

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: I’m good.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Why not? Jason gets up and walks away from the water.

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: To the bathroom.  31.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA/LINDSEY
dialogues.text: Why don’t you pee in the ocean?

dialogues.speaker: LINDSEY
dialogues.text: Jinx.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty and Adelaide don’t notice.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: You ever wish you kept dancing?

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: I mean you were, like, really good right?

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: I peaked at fourteen.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: Didn’t we all? Jason passes by them as he heads towards the Port-O-Potti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason takes a long walk past sunbathers and other people the port-o-potty near the boardwalk, becoming increasingl remote from the group. When he arrives at the port-o-pott sour older lady emerges. He lets her pass and then goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adelaide continues with Kitty.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: There was this one competition where I did a piece from “The Nutcracker”...

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: I love “The Nutcracker.”  32.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: You know the ‘Grand Pas de Deux’? It’s the pretty one, at the end of the ballet.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: Oh! Where she flies into the prince’s arms.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: Okay, can I tell you? I cry at that part every time. Josh interrupts from afar.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: You cry? Really?

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: (To Josh) No one’s talking to you. (To Adelaide) You were saying...

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: The ‘Grand Pas’ is supposed to be a dance for two, but I turned it into a solo.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: Um... that’s badass.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Nerve-racking. I thought I’d get disqualified, but when I finished the audience went crazy. I won first prize. It was the best moment of my life...besides Zora and Jason's birth.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: The girls don’t make my top ten, by the way. I’m convinced I would be a movie star if I didn’t have them at exactly the wrong time... Adelaide starts watching people on the beach around them Kitty drones on. A guy chases his girlfriend who screams. small group of people laugh hard. A teen play fights with brother. Each vignette seems to make Adelaide increasingl nervous but she hides it well.  33.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...I trained at Stella Adler and booked two commercials before I met Josh, and totally stopped auditioning when I got preggers. Then the move to San Fransisco was like a fucking career killer. The whole thing was supposed to be I would fly out for auditions but that never happened. I put myself on tape for like half a year, but it’s really not the same. You have to be in the room for things to fall into place. A red frisbee falls onto the towel they’re sitting on. Adelaide is startled.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jesus! (To Adelaide) Oh, look. Adelaide looks down. The frisbee has landed perfectly on of the towel’s large, printed polka dots. Adelaide picks up, revealing the same colored dot underneath. It really eerily perfect. Adelaide is quietly concerned.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whoa. That’s crazy. We’ve been having so many weird coincidences happening lately. A guy runs over to claim the frisbee. Adelaide gives it t him.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Thanks. He leaves. Adelaide looks over and sees the twins playing near Zora. No Jason.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: No “I'm sorry”? Dick. Anyway, we should go back to our place. I think it’s ‘vodka ‘o clock.’

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Where’s Jason?  34.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BEACH PORT-O-POTTY. DAY
dialogues.text: Jason comes out of the port-o-potty and starts walking ba to the beach but stops when he notices something strange. man stands facing away from him on the beach about twenty yards away. The man has his arms stretched out at his sid in a relaxed manner, like a yoga pose. Other people walk around him, only occasionally noticing him. Jason is transfixed. He walks slowly and wide around the man tryin see his face. It’s tense.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BEACH. PICNIC. DAY
dialogues.text: Adelaide looks around with increasing concern.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Where’s Jason?

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: (looking) He's...

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Gabe..? Where’s Jason? Gabe looks around.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (calling out) Jason...?! Jason...!!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BEACH PORT-O-POTTY. DAY
dialogues.text: Jason takes another step towards the strange man with outstretched arms. He can almost see his profile. He stop when he notices the man has dried blood on his hands.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Jason! !!! Jason runs back scared.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BEACH. DAY
dialogues.text: Jason arrives back at Adelaide’s side.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Where were you?!

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: I went to the bathroom.  35.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: No! You don’t do that. You don’t run off without telling me...?! She shakes him.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Ow! Jason’s shoulder is hurt. He looks scared. Adelaide looks around. Everyone nearby watches. She catches her breath a hugs him.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Don’t do that to me, understand?! Josh and Kitty look at each other. Little awkward.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: (Josh and Kitty) Long day. Let’s get together tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: (To the voyeurs) Show’s over, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WOODED ROAD. DUSK
dialogues.text: The Wilsons drive home.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAR. DUSK
dialogues.text: The Wilsons are sun-beaten and tired. They're all still a little shaken from Adelaide's freak-out. The radio is on.

dialogues.speaker: NEWS RADIO ANCHOR
dialogues.text: And authorities are in an active investigation of several stabbings that occurred earlier today originally thought to be unrelated, but authorities now say they are investigating possible links... Adelaide turns the radio off. INT. WILSON’S CAR. NIGHT The Wilson’s pull into the driveway. All is quiet. Gabe suddenly turns to the kids in the back.  36. INT. WILSON'S BAYSIDE HOUSE. FAMILY ROOM. NIGHT. Gabe lays on the couch watching TV. Adelaide closes the curtains.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: .»-You saw their new car right? He had to do it. He just had to get that thing to fuck with me too. Jason runs down the hallway to his room.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: I guess mission accomplished. (Yelling to Jason) Don’t run! Zora comes out of the bathroom and stops by Jason's. INT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. JASON’S BEDROOM. NIGHT As Jason lands on his bed, Zora enters.

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: Way to freak mom out. She leaves. INT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. FAMILY ROOM. NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: You good? Adelaide nods unconvincingly.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I’m gonna say goodnight. Adelaide starts going down the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Okay... I’m just waiting for the Giants highlights. I’1l see you in the magic room. INT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. ZORA'S ROOM. NIGHT Adelaide peeks in. Zora is under her blanket. It glows wi the light of the phone.  37.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Night night.

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: Goodnight...

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Phone off. After a beat the light goes off. Adelaide walks away. The light goes back on. INT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. JASON’S ROOM. NIGHT Jason sits on his bed by his window.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Look. He points too his digital alarm clock which displays “11: Adelaide pauses.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Past your bedtime... Jason tries to snap his “spark starter”

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you want, we can go into town tomorrow and get you a new one.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: It’s okay. Grandma got me this one. Adelaide enters and sits on his bed.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Mask off. She takes his mask off rubs his head and kisses it.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: You thought I was dead?

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Oh. No... I didn’t know if you were lost, or taken...

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: By bad people, right? Like terrorists and psychos.  38.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Yes, there are. As long as you’re with me, I’ll keep you safe... Okay? Jason nods. Adelaide gets up and goes to the door. She se drawing of a stick figure facing another stick figure who faces away from the first.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who is this? Jason shrugs. Adelaide She goes to the window and closes the curtains. Jason looks at her. He’s confused but nods in agreement. Adelaide, shook, nods as well. INT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. MASTER BEDROOM. NIGHT Adelaide stares out the window. Gabe enters brushing his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: You know, I was thinking about getting fishing gear tomorrow. Four rods. We could all go. We could fish from the dock. Of course, there’s the boat too. If we get out there in open water, just sayin’, but I’m not trying to force anyone... He notices Adelaide’s stillness.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey... She doesn’t answer, just stares out the window transfixed Gabe looks in the direction she’s looking, but sees nothi

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: I want to go.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Go? Where?

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Home. I can’t be here. It’s too much.  39.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: You serious?

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Being here, it’s like there’s this black cloud hanging over me, and... I don’t feel like myself.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Well I think you’re you.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Gabe, I need to tell you something and I just need you to listen.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Okay...

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: When I was a kid I went to that boardwalk with my parents. I wandered off. I don’t know why, but I did. I ended up in that hall of mirrors, and... FLASHBACK...

dialogues.speaker: INT. VISION QUEST. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Young Adelaide stands in the dark mirror-lined hallway as last left off. She faces the back of the other girls head PRESENT DAY...

dialogues.speaker: INT. WILSON'S BAYSIDE HOUSE. MASTER BEDROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Adelaide stares out the window. Gabe’s on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: .-.-There was another girl in there. She looked like me... Exactly like me. FLASHBACK...

dialogues.speaker: INT. VISION QUEST. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Adelaide stares, stunned by the back of what she thought a reflection. Now the other girl begins turning towards Adelaide reveal  40.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: an intense, hateful smile that pierces through the darkne She’s shrouded in darkness, but from what we can make out looks just like Adelaide. PRESENT DAY... INT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. MASTER BEDROOM. NIGHT Gabe, on the bed, is confused and silent for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: You were in a house of mirrors--

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: --No. She wasn’t a reflection. She was real. She... Flashback...

dialogues.speaker: INT. VISION QUEST. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Before Adelaide can scream, the other girl grabs her by t throat with both hands and SCREAMS IN HER FACE WITH GLEEF RAGE. Present day... INT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. MASTER BEDROOM. NIGHT Adelaide confides in Gabe.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: -..-She tried to kill me. She tried to choke me. I got away; I ran as fast as I could. My whole life I've felt like she’s still coming for me.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Whatever happened, it was a long, time ago.--

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: --You know when things line up? The coincidences..? Since we’ve been up here they’ve been happening more and more... I think they mean she’s getting closer.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: The girl who looks like you?  41.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: You don’t believe me.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: I do, I do... I’m just... processing... He looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know I’m here, right? I mean, I'm pretty sure I could kick your as, so if she looks like you... Okay, not funny. My bad, I’m just tryin’ to lighten the mood-- The lights cut out.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ah, shit.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Perfect timing. See, this is why Josh has a back up generator... Gabe starts towards the door. Jason stands in the doorway Gabe is startled.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jesus. We lost power. I’m gonna fix it. Go back to bed.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: There’s a family in our driveway. Adelaide and Gabe look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: INT. WILSON BAYSIDE HOUSE. FOYER. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Adelaide, Gabe and Jason stand out the front door window. Four people stand near the edge of the property silhouett by the moonlight. Their contour seem to fit the same fami archetypes as the Wilsons themselves. On the left, a boy: hunched and wavering; Next to him, a father: hulking with head tilted oddly; Next, a mother: still and poised. On t right, a daughter: thin and sleek. Adelaide watches in horror.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: (to himself) Huh. Now who is that?

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: We have to get out of here. Hold on. It’s just a family. You scared of a family?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: .--A boogie man’s family. Zora enters from the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Zora, give me your phone?

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: I’m not on it!

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Zora. She hands Adelaide the phone. Adelaide calls 911.

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: Who’s that?

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: It's just a family... outside..

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: It’s standing . probably neighbors. You're kidding me right?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: I’m scared.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: (to operator) Hello. My name is Adelaide Wilson. We're at 2311 Seagull Way...

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Whoa. You really callin’ 911? Look. Everything’s good. We lost power alright? I’m gonna fix it, and I’m gonna find out what they want. Let’s all try not to freak out.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There are four trespassers here on our property... Yes... No we don’t... Can you send us someone immediately; I don’t think we’re safe.  43.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Gabe unlocks the door.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gabe!!

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: Dad.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: They probably need help. Hang tight. Gabe walks out. EXT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. FRONT LAWN. NIGHT Gabe opens the front door and steps out trying to look confident and casual.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Out here tryin’ to have a vacation; my whole family’s lost their damn minds. The four figures stand there, evenly spaced, about fiftee yards away from the house.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey! The figures look dead at him.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can I help you? Nothing. INT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. FOYER. NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Fourteen minutes..? No... No... Tell them to come faster...

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: Mom. .?

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Okay... Yes, yes. Hurry! Gabe!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WILSON'S BAYSIDE HOUSE. FRONT LAWN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Gabe takes a couple steps towards the strangers. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: If y'all are out here tryin’ to scare people, you picked the wrong house for that... Gabe squints to try to see their faces.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (losing confidence as he goes) Okay, I asked you nice. Now I’m gonna need you get off my... get off my property. Gabe almost says something else, but the lack of motion o response from the strangers tells him something might in be very wrong.

dialogues.speaker: INT. WILSON'S BAYSIDE HOUSE. FOYER/LIVING ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Gabe backs into the house. He’s shook. That’s not how he expected that to go.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Okay, let’s call the cops.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: I did. They’re fourteen minutes away.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: What...? Fourteen minutes? Okay... Jason, get me the bat.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: The bat?

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: The baseball bat... The bat! There’s one in the--

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: Here. Zora rushes gets the bat from the closet and brings it to Gabe.  45.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Gabe...

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Okay, hold on. I’m gonna try again.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: It’s okay... It’s okay... Gabe starts out the door.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WILSON'S BAYSIDE HOUSE. FRONT LAWN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Gabe walks out. He means business this time.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: The cops’1l be here any minute., So... They know you're trespassing and harassing us... Again, they do nothing.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, well. Suit yourselves. If I were you, I’d-- All of a sudden, with a quick and coordinated dart, the “ FAMILY" break formation. Gabe shudders. The “BAD DAUGHTER goes left, and the “BAD SON” gets on all fours and scurri right. Gabe falls back instinctively as the “BAD FATHER” comes directly towards him.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, hey, hey... INT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. FOYER/LIVING ROOM. NIGHT Gabe backs up into the house and shuts the door just as t “Bad Father” arrives with a SLAM.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: They're going around. Is the back door locked?

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: My window’s open! Zora takes off running towards her room.  46.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Zora, no! Adelaide leaves Jason to pursue Zora. INT. WILSON'S BAYSIDE HOUSE. ZORA’S BEDROOM. NIGHT Zora makes it to her window and locks it just as the “Bad Daughter” climbs up a tree with lizard speed. Zora starts backing out of the room terrified as Adelaide comes and g her.

dialogues.speaker: INT. WILSON'S HOUSE. FOYER/LIVING ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The front door THUMPS rhythmically.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: I’m serious, man your damn head!! t!! I will break

dialogues.speaker: INT. WILSON BAYSIDE HOUSE. KITCHEN BREAKFAST TABLE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Jason looks at a nearby window. He gets closer to the gla and tries to peek out... Suddenly the “Bad Son’s” head pops up close. He wears a rubber burn mask. Adelaide rushes in with Zora and pulls Jason close. A SHARP WHISTLE cuts through the silence. That familiar t “Itsy Bitsy Spider,” terrorizes Adelaide. It’s her. The “BAD MOTHER” walks slowly past the windows towards the front door. A few FOOTSTEPS THUMP on the roof.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WILSON'S BAYSIDE HOUSE. FRONT LAWN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: We still can’t see their faces, but the “Bad Mother” arri at the front door. The “Bad Father” stops BANGING THE DOO She lifts a rock near the front steps.

dialogues.speaker: INT. WILSON'S BAYSIDE HOUSE. FOYER/LIVING ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Gabe takes a few deep breaths while the family huddles be him in the living room.  47.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Suddenly from outside a KEY GOES IN THE LOCK!

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: The key.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: What key?!

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: The damn “Hide-a-key!”

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Hide-a-key”? What kind of white- shit...?!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens with force. Gabe tries to hold it shut, bu the Bad Father opens it anyway. He swings at the “Bad Fat who catches the bat and takes it away, as if Gabe were a child. He brings the bat down on Gabe’s knee with a CRACK Gabe goes down.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Aaaaahhhhhggg!!!! Adelaide, Zora and Jason back up into the living room. To their left, the “Bad Son,” obscured by curtains scurries the window. To their right, a Sky light crashes. The “Bad Daughter,” falls into the kitchen. The “Bad Father” and “Bad Daughter” back the Wilsons into Living room as the “Bad Son” scurries past the windows. Adelaide holds her children close as Gabe tries to get up Wincing, he stumbles back into the living room in agony. “Bad Father” follows him in to the room slowly, bat in ha

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: (whispers) Mom?

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: It’s okay. Just stay close. The “Bad Daughter” turns into the living room. The “Bad Mother” enters. She is RED, Adelaide’s dopplegan She walks in a calm erudite manner; the clear head of her family. It’s dark. Red arrives at the chair in front of them and sits. She motions for them to sit.  48.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The “Bad Son”, smashes a hole in the back porch door wind and enters. The Wilson's sit on the couch. Except for Gabe who tries stand aided by the arm of the couch. The “Bad Son” lights a match in his hand with a SNAP. The fireplace erupts in flames. The fire backlights the “Bad Family.” The “Bad Son” shuff to Red's side and sits like a dog. She strokes his masked head. We still can’t really see their features in full, but at point it’s clear that these home invaders are DOPPLEGANGE of the Wilsons. ABRAHAM, Gabe’'s doppleganger, seems a little out of it. attention wanders like a rampage killer lost in some kind psychotic break. UMBRAE, Zora’s doppleganger, stands with perfect posture, sleeked back hair, and an evil little smirk. PLUTO, Jason’s doppleganger, breathes thick under his mas He carries himself like an animal. The entire “Bad Family” wear red jumpsuits with and sanda and one glove. Zora starts freaking out.

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: What..? What..?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: (under his breath) It’s us. Gabe isn’t ready to believe what’s in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: We don’t have anything here. This is our summer home. We got in today, so--.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: --Gabe... Red clears her throat silencing Gabe. She speaks. Her voi is quiet and craggy like it’s never been used.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: Once upon a time, there was a girl, and the girl had a shadow. The two were connected; tethered together. So whatever happened to the girl happened to the shadow... When the girl ate, her food was given to her, warm and tasty, but when the shadow was hungry, she had to eat rabbits, raw and bloody. On Christmas the girl received wonderful toys, soft and cushy, but the shadow’s toys were so sharp and cold they’d slice through her fingers when she played with them. Time passed. They both got older, and one day the girl met a handsome prince and fell in love. At that same time, the shadow met Abraham. It didn’t matter if she loved him or not, he was tethered to the girl's prince after all. Then the girl had her first child; a beautiful baby girl... but the shadow... she gave birth to a little monster. Umbrae was born laughing. The girl had a second child, a boy this time. They had to cut her open and take him from her belly. The shadow had to do it all herself. She named him Pluto. He was born to love fire. Pluto growls at Gabe. RED (CONT’D) So you see, the Shadow hated the girl so much for so long, until one day she realized that she wasn’t being punished by the girl at all. She was being tested by God. INT. WILSON HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. NIGHT. Gabe tries to present a non-chalant tone, and pull Red’s attention off Adelaide.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Look, Here’s my wallet. Take the car.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Gabe.--  50.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: --Take whatever you want. Hell, you can take the boat, for all I care.

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: (through tears) Nobody wants the boat, dad.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: How about this. Take me to the ATM. I’ll get all the cash I can take out, and you can go. We won’t say... We won’t say shit.. Gabe, who has been in denial of the supernatural element play, loses steam.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you people? He finally gets Red’s attention. She turns her head, disappointed with the question.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: What are we...? Red leans in. RED (CONT’D) ...We’re Americans. Red holds up bronze colored handcuffs. She gives them to Pluto who walks to Adelaide and stands on the table. RED (CONT’D) Tether yourself to the table.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Addy... no. Don’t--

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: (to Gabe) --Or maybe I should cut something off of you. Abraham takes a step towards Gabe.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Just don’t hurt the children. Adelaide puts the handcuffs on one wrist and in connects to the heavy coffee table.  51.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Hey, hey...! Abraham grabs him by the wrist. Gabe tries to resist, but knee is jacked and he’s simply not as strong.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey. Don’t touch me. Get off!

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: No! Abraham pulls Gabe out the back living room door and off back poRch. It’s easy as if he’s dragging a toddler in fu tantrum.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay... okay...

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: (To Zora) Little girl... Zora shrinks in fear.

dialogues.speaker: ZORA
dialogues.text: Mom?

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: Run. Umbrae takes a menacing step towards Zora who gets up off couch. Zora looks at Adelaide who nods at her. Zora quick runs to the front door. Umbrae slinks after her.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: (To Red) You want me right? EXT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. FRONT LAWN. NIGHT Zora bursts out the door and runs fast down the street. Umbrae walks into the middle of the street and watches he run. She stretches her arms and legs. INT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. FOYER/LIVING ROOM. NIGHT Adelaide holds Jason tight on the couch. Red pets Pluto.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: Go play, boys.  52.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Pluto hops on the coffee table and hold his hand out to J like a trained animal.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Mom?

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: No. He’s not going.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: Be careful. He has a temper. Pluto starts to growl. Adelaide holds it together, but he voice shakes. She looks in Jason’s eyes which he diverts.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Okay. Okay. It’s okay. Look at me. You're going to be okay. Show him one of your tricks. Adelaide gives Jason a look that seems to say “be smart.” Jason's scared, but he stands. Pluto grunts jovially and follows him upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: Don’t burn the house down. Red and Adelaide are alone in the living room. They sit across from one another in silence. EXT. WILSON’S BACK YARD. NIGHT Abraham kicks Gabe, who can barely stand, down the back p stairs. Abraham follows him down slowly.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Ok, wait. Wait, wait, wait--

dialogues.speaker: ABRAHAM
dialogues.text: Blahflabumbalavlamlubala!!!!! Abraham knocks Gabe out with the blunt end of his scissor He looks over at some garbage nearby.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WILSON'S HOUSE. FRONT LAWN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Zora is about 100 yards away and still running hard. At t end of the street is a house. Umbrae slowly walks back and forth, stretching her arms i anticipation. She watches Zora get smaller in the distanc  53.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Gabe can be heard struggling on the other side of the hou

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No!!! No!!! INT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. FOYER/LIVING ROOM. NIGHT Red watches Adelaide hear Gabe’s cries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pluto leads Jason into the closet. Jason moves a sock in door crack with his foot so the door can’t shut all the w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pluto breathes heavily under the mask. Jason raises his a and Pluto does the same, mirroring him.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WILSON'S BAYSIDE HOUSE. FRONT LAWN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Zora is now almost gone down the street. Umbrae finishes pacing and joint cracking. INT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. FOYER/LIVING ROOM . NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: What do you want? Red watches her.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: Years ago I had a vision. In this vision I saw a line of blood on the soil that stretched as far as I could see. Red stands. She slowly walks to Adelaide’s side.

dialogues.speaker: RED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: During this vision God spoke to me. He said “the only way for a soul to truly be free is to sever the tie”. And his voice... It was the most beautiful sound I’ve ever heard...  54.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A moment of silence. Red places her hand on Adelaide’s he and slowly pushes it to the table. RED (CONT’D) I call it “The Untethering.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pluto holds a lit match. Jason is so scared, but starts t lift Pluto’s mask. Before we can see his face, the match out. It’s dark again. Pluto strikes another match and illuminates his awful face. It’s identical to Jason’s but bottom half is covered in burn scars. Jason WHIMPERS.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DOWN THE STREET. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Zora is out of breath. Her running slows to a walk. She t to look behind her, but doesn’t see anything. She turns forward and keeps walking just as we see a shadowy figure come into view in the distance behind her, closing in fas After a few paces, she turns around just as the figure ru wide behind her. Again, she sees nothing. Crying, she tur back to proceed and finds herself face-to-face with Umbra who's curled around in front of her. Zora SCREAMS. INT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. FOYER/LIVING ROOM. NIGHT Red continues to Adelaide’s face on the coffee table.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: I’ve wondered if you did too... See this day coming. The glass starts to splinter. Red is so strong.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DOWN THE STREET. NIGHT
dialogues.text: With little steam left. Zora runs around a car; Umbrae go to the other side of it. Zora sees Umbrae stalking her through the windows. Suddenly Umbrae goes down disappeari behind the door. Zora terrified goes down too. She looks underneath but sees nothing; no feet. Zora looks up. Umbr is on the roof of the car leaning over her  55.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. OPEN WATER. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The MOTORBOAT BUZZES. Gabe comes to in pitch black. He po a hole. He’s in a garbage bag, lying in the back of his o boat. He looks through the torn hole at Abraham who stand the steering wheel with his back to Gabe. Gabe looks arou The bat is propped up by Abraham who also has his scissor his hand. There’s a life preserver floatation device atta to a coiled rope and tethered to the boat. Gabe starts slowly and quietly to pull himself out of the bag. He peers behind them. The lights of the shore are fa and getting further away. He reaches for the floatation device and slowly pulls it towards him. Suddenly the boat’s motor coughs. It’s faili Abraham turns as Gabe shrinks back into the garbage bag. Abraham walks over. He doesn’t notice the coil of unwound rope he’s standing inside of. Abraham begins BANGING the motor exactly the way Gabe did earlier. It’s being stubborn. Gabe slowly crawls forward and gets the bat. He sneaks up behind Abraham and swings just as Abraham turns around, knocking him off the boat. As he falls, the rope tangles around Abraham’s foot, cinching into a knot. The floatati device and rope goes overboard with him.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Ha, ha..! Fuck you! Gabe hits the motor with the bat in triumph; the motor re into action. The boat takes off, sending Gabe off the bac and into the water. The boat drives away. Gabe wades frantically. He looks around, but doesn’t see Abraham. Then... Suddenly, Abraham surfaces and swings his scissor Gabe but the boat is now far enough away that the rope ar Abraham’s ankle goes taught and he is pulled away. Gabe is left there, bobbing in the water, as the boat pul Abraham away on his belly, like an unwilling waterskier. Gabe watches, as the boat WHIRS away into the dark, night water.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Goodbye. INT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. UPSTAIRS CLOSET. NIGHT Pluto continues to mirror Jason’s wrist. Jason starts his snapping. Pluto snaps, lighting a match. Pluto is intrigu  56.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The snapping continues, but nothing happens. Pluto’s GUTT BREATHs BUILD TO AN ANGRY GRUNT.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DOWN THE STREET. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Umbrae gets closer and closer to Zora. Just then DON, a large old man, comes out of the nearby house.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: The Fuck?! Get off my car! Umbrae turns. Zora takes the moment to flee back towards house. DON (CONT’D) Come here. Come here... Umbrae gets off the car ready to pursue Zora. Don walks towards Umbrae. DON (CONT’D) Hey, kid! I’m talking to you. Umbrae stops at “kid”. Now she’s angry. As Zora runs, huffing and puffing, Umbrae goes down and severs his Achilles tendon with her scissors. He screams falls to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. OPEN WATER. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Moments later, Gabe hears the boat’s motor getting louder again. He prepares himself and faces the boat, but when i about 25 yards from him the MOTOR SPUTTERS out again. The boat slows to a glide and stops near him. Gabe looks for Abraham, but doesn’t see him. The life preserver floats b him. No Abraham. Gabe grabs the rope and pulls himself towards the boat. He climbs up the back of the boat just as Abraham attacks from behind. Gabe hangs on the back of the boat with Abra hanging onto him. Gabe hits the motor twice and it turns Abraham, who's torso is pressed against the propeller get SLASHED across his chest and face as he falls back into t water. Gabe, exhausted, falls into the boat as it drives away.  57. INT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. UPSTAIRS CLOSET. NIGHT As Pluto grunts, Jason begins snapping.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Wait. Wait. Look. Pluto becomes curious and watches Jason’s hand. Jason sna faster and faster when, suddenly, the trick works! A few sparks fly from Jason’s fingers catching Pluto entirely o guard. He’s startled. Jason uses the moment to knock him and run out of the closet. INT. WILSON’S HOUSE. FOYER/LIVING ROOM. NIGHT Red holds Adelaide down. The coffee table cracks even mor Blood starts to pool on the side of Adelaide's face. INT. WILSON’S BEACH HOUSE. UPSTAIRS HALLWAY. NIGHT Jason trips and falls into the hallway. Pluto, confused, up and lunges towards Jason, but Jason pulls the sock out with his toes and SLAMS the door, just in time, with his other foot. Pluto SCREAMS.

dialogues.speaker: INT. WILSON'S BAYSIDE HOUSE. FOYER/LIVING ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Adelaide and Red hear the SCREAM. They watch each other f moment.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: That’s yours. Red's still for a moment. Then, suddenly, she stands and leaves the room headed towards Pluto. Now alone, Adelaide leaps into action. First, she tries t get out of the cuffs, but can’t. She tries to break the t with her foot. She sees the fire poker across the room an goes towards it, but is stopped again by the heavy table. INT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. HALLWAY. NIGHT Red opens the closet. Pluto’s inside. He stops yelling. H exits and looks around sniffing the air. Jason is nowhere be seen. Pluto skitters into Jason’s room. Red starts wal down the hallway in search of Jason.  58.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She takes a step into Zora’s room. Red comes out. She see the basement door is open and goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: INT. WILSON'S BAYSIDE HOUSE. FOYER/LIVING ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Adelaide sees the phone. She grabs it, dials ‘911’ again drags the coffee table a little. As the phone rings, she slowly pulls the coffee table tow the fire poker.

dialogues.speaker: RECORDED VOICE
dialogues.text: All of our operators are currently busy. Please hang on the line... Adelaide is close enough to almost reach.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Come on... She grabs the fire poker, barely. She darts over to the coffee table and uses the poker and all of her strength t quietly pry the wooden leg off the table. Adelaide does enough damage to the coffee table to free herself! INT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. BASEMENT. NIGHT Red walks through the basement looking for Jason. She fin the box of keepsakes, picks up the stuffed bunny and look it. INT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. HALLWAY. NIGHT Adelaide looks down the hallway. She sees no one. She whispers.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
